measured_by: Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration Scale (BPNSWS)
justification: The Methods section states: “Basic Psychological Need Satisfaction and Frustration Scale (BPNSWS)… consists of eight items each for the satisfaction and frustration of each of the three basic psychological need… and were rated on a scale from 1 (Completely disagree) to 6 (Completely agree).”
construct: Basic psychological need satisfaction (autonomy, competence, relatedness)

justification: Under “Preference for Automation Types (PAT)” the authors note they “developed a questionnaire with four sub-scales with four items each… Participants’ instructions were to indicate the degree to which they preferred the steps be carried out by a human or an automated system.”

measured_by: Single-item slider rating based on Expectancy-Value Theory
justification: In the EVT-Ratings description the paper explains that participants “were then asked to evaluate 23 specific tasks… Rating was conducted on single-item sliders (0 = extremely low to 5 = extremely high).”

measured_by: Single-item slider rating based on Expectancy-Value Theory
justification: The same EVT-Ratings section specifies that success expectancy was one of the three criteria each task was rated on using the single-item slider scales.

measured_by: Single-item slider rating based on Expectancy-Value Theory
justification: The EVT-Ratings procedure notes that the third rated dimension was Cost, assessed with the same 0–5 single-item slider.

measured_by: Propensity to Trust in Automation scale (PTT)
justification: In the simulator study description the authors report: “Propensity to Trust in Automation (PTT)… was rated on a 6-point Likert scale from ‘Completely disagree’ to ‘Completely agree’ (M = 3.8, SD = 0.4).”

The same paragraph states: “Affinity for Technology Interaction (ATI) evaluates a person’s tendency to engage actively in technology interaction… Using the same 6-point scale as PTT, participants had an above-average ATI (M = 4.3, SD = 0.8).”
